definitions: The developmental period between childhood and adulthood marked by rapid physical and hormonal changes.
A growth-and-maturation stage characterized by puberty-related endocrine shifts and accelerated physical development.
The transition phase where biological maturation speeds up and body proportions/strength change quickly.
A life stage often including peak height velocity and major changes in body composition and neuromuscular control.
The period when sexual maturation occurs and training responses can change due to hormonal environment.
A developmental window with rapid growth that can temporarily affect coordination and injury risk.
The stage between childhood and adulthood where physiological systems mature toward adult capacity.
A maturation phase where growth rate increases, then slows as adult stature is approached.
The stage of life following adolescence characterized by physical maturity.
A life phase in which growth in height has largely ceased and biological systems are fully mature.
The post-maturation period where training adaptations occur in a relatively stable physiological state.
A stage defined by completed development of reproductive and musculoskeletal systems.
The phase after puberty/PHV where adult body size and proportions are established.
A period where performance changes are driven more by training, recovery, and aging than growth.
The mature life stage following adolescence, with stabilized endocrine and skeletal growth patterns.
A stage of life in which biological age and chronological age often align more closely than in youth.
The absence of menstruation, often associated with low energy availability and the female athlete triad.
A menstrual disturbance in which normal menstrual cycles stop or do not occur.
Loss of menstrual function frequently linked to insufficient caloric intake relative to training demands.
A key red-flag sign of disrupted reproductive hormone signaling in active females.
Menstrual absence that can indicate low energy availability and increased risk to bone health.
A symptom that may reflect endocrine suppression due to chronic energy deficit and/or stress.
A menstrual dysfunction often discussed within the female athlete triad/RED-S context.
Absence of menses that can be associated with decreased estrogen and compromised bone density.
A ligament in the knee that provides rotational stability and resists anterior tibial translation.
A major knee stabilizer that limits forward movement of the tibia relative to the femur.
A ligament that helps control knee valgus/rotation stresses during cutting and landing.
A key passive restraint that contributes to knee joint stability in multi-planar movements.
A knee ligament commonly injured in pivoting sports, especially with deceleration and change of direction.
A structure that resists anterior shear forces on the tibia and helps stabilize knee rotation.
A stabilizing ligament whose injury often occurs with noncontact cutting/landing mechanics.
A ligament critical for knee stability during rapid deceleration, pivoting, and jumping/landing.
Relating to a secondary ossification center where tendons attach to bone.
Pertaining to an apophysis, a bony outgrowth serving as a tendon/ligament attachment site.
Describing growth regions where traction forces from tendons can affect developing bone.
A term often used in youth injury contexts where tendon attachment sites are still developing.
Relating to areas that ossify separately from the main bone shaft and fuse later.
Associated with secondary growth centers that can be vulnerable to traction overuse in youth.
Referring to tendon attachment growth centers (apophyses) rather than joint surfaces.
Describing structures involving secondary ossification sites where muscles/tendons anchor.
An assessment of physiological and developmental maturity rather than chronological years.
A measure of how mature the body is biologically, independent of calendar age.
A maturity indicator that reflects developmental status (e.g., puberty timing, growth stage).
An estimate of maturation level that can differ significantly among same-aged peers.
A way to describe developmental progress toward adult state, not simply years since birth.
A maturity-based age metric useful when considering training readiness in youth athletes.
A developmental assessment that reflects physiological maturation rather than birthdate.
A measure of growth/maturity stage that helps explain performance differences in youth.
The developmental stage before adolescence characterized by steady growth.
A pre-pubertal life stage with relatively stable, gradual increases in height and mass.
A growth phase where endocrine changes of puberty have not yet accelerated development.
A period when skill learning and movement literacy are often highly trainable.
The stage prior to puberty where biological maturation is progressing but not accelerated.
A developmental window typically marked by steady growth and improving neuromuscular coordination.
A pre-adolescent phase in which growth is consistent and less variable than during puberty.
The life stage before adolescent growth spurts and major hormonal changes begin.
Age measured in years since birth.
The number of years (and months) elapsed since a person’s birthdate.
A time-based age measure that may not reflect biological maturity in youth.
Calendar age used for grouping athletes but not always predictive of readiness.
A simple age metric that does not account for differences in maturation timing.
The official age in years, often used for competition categories and eligibility.
The count of time since birth, distinct from physiological or biological age.
An age classification based on birthdate rather than developmental stage.
Simultaneous activation of agonist and antagonist muscles to enhance joint stability.
Co-activation of opposing muscle groups to stiffen a joint and improve control.
A stabilization strategy where both sides of a joint produce force at the same time.
A neuromuscular pattern that increases joint stiffness, often used during landing or cutting.
Concurrent activation of prime movers and their opposers to protect and stabilize joints.
A control mechanism that can reduce joint shear/translation by increasing stiffness.
A strategy that improves stability but can reduce net torque if excessive.
Simultaneous muscle activation around a joint to enhance alignment and stability.
The process of growth, maturation, and functional change over time.
Long-term progression of physical, cognitive, and physiological capacities across lifespan.
A broad term describing changes in structure and function as an individual ages and matures.
The combination of growth in size and maturation of systems and skills.
The ongoing process of change in capabilities from childhood through adulthood and aging.
A lifespan process including growth, biological maturation, and improved functional capacity.
Changes in body systems and abilities over time due to maturation and experience.
The overall trajectory of functional and structural change from youth to older adulthood.
The shaft or midsection of a long bone.
The long central portion of a long bone between the ends (epiphyses).
The tubular bone shaft that provides leverage and structural strength.
The midsection region of long bones that houses marrow cavity in many bones.
The main body of a long bone, typically composed largely of cortical bone.
The central segment of long bones that contributes to bending strength and support.
The elongated shaft portion of a long bone, not the joint-forming ends.
The primary structural shaft of a long bone, connecting proximal and distal ends.
A somatotype characterized by a lean body structure and low fat mass.
A body type typically described as slender with relatively low body mass and fat stores.
A somatotype associated with narrow frame, lower muscle mass, and linear build.
A classification often linked to endurance-friendly physiques (general trend, not destiny).
A lean somatotype with less relative mass around limbs and trunk.
A somatotype characterized by long limbs and a smaller cross-sectional build.
A body-type descriptor emphasizing leanness and relatively low adiposity.
A somatotype typically described as “thin/linear,” with low fat and smaller frame.
A somatotype characterized by higher fat accumulation and rounder body shape.
A body type often described as softer, with greater relative adiposity.
A somatotype with a tendency toward higher body fat and broader circumference measures.
A classification associated with rounder physique and potentially easier mass gain (general trend).
A somatotype described by higher fat storage and less linear appearance.
A body-type descriptor emphasizing higher adiposity and rounder body contours.
A somatotype often characterized by greater fat mass and thicker trunk/limbs.
A physique classification typically described as “rounder,” with higher relative fat stores.
A condition involving low energy availability, menstrual dysfunction, and low bone mineral density.
A health pattern in active females combining inadequate energy intake, hormonal disruption, and bone loss risk.
Interrelated problems: insufficient energy availability, irregular/absent menses, and compromised bone health.
A syndrome linking under-fueling to reproductive hormone changes and reduced skeletal integrity.
A triad of low energy, menstrual disturbances, and low BMD that increases injury risk.
A clinical framework describing under-fueling leading to menstrual and bone density consequences.
A set of conditions in athletes where energy deficit impacts menstrual function and bone strength.
A syndrome in which low energy availability can drive amenorrhea and decreased bone mineral density.
An increase in body size or tissue mass.
A measurable increase in stature, mass, or organ/tissue size over time.
The process of becoming larger in physical dimensions (height, weight, tissue volume).
A size-based change distinct from maturation, which is about functional/biological readiness.
An increase in body dimensions due to tissue accumulation and skeletal elongation.
A change in body size commonly tracked via height, weight, and limb segment changes.
A physical size increase that occurs across development, especially in youth.
An increase in tissue quantity (e.g., bone length, muscle size) over time.
Cartilage responsible for longitudinal bone growth, such as epiphyseal plates.
Cartilaginous tissue at growth plates enabling long bone lengthening during development.
The cartilage regions where bones lengthen before ossifying into adult bone.
Tissue at the ends of long bones that supports height growth until closure.
The cartilage responsible for bone elongation in youth, later replaced by bone.
Growth plate cartilage that allows longitudinal growth via endochondral ossification.
Cartilage structures that permit bone length increases during childhood/adolescence.
The growth plate-related cartilage that supports bone lengthening before maturation.
The process of progressing toward the adult state of biological development.
Developmental progression of physiological systems toward adult function and structure.
The biological process by which tissues and systems become fully developed.
A timeline of becoming ‘adult-like’ in function, not just increasing in size.
The process of achieving full biological development (e.g., puberty completion).
Progression toward adult physiological capability and skeletal maturity.
Biological development stage advancement independent of chronological age.
The transition toward adult state in growth plates, hormones, and system function.
The onset of the first menstrual cycle.
The first occurrence of menstruation, marking a milestone in female puberty.
A pubertal event indicating maturation of the reproductive endocrine system.
The first menstrual period, often used as a maturation marker in youth female athletes.
The initial menstrual bleeding event signaling reproductive maturation progress.
The beginning of menstrual function during puberty in females.
A developmental milestone marking the start of menstrual cycles.
The first menstrual period, commonly referenced when discussing maturation timing.
A somatotype characterized by muscularity and athletic build.
A body type often described as naturally more muscular with broader shoulders and stronger frame.
A somatotype associated with greater relative lean mass and robust physique.
A physique classification emphasizing muscular development and athletic proportions.
A body-type descriptor associated with higher muscle mass and strength potential (general trend).
A somatotype typically described as strong/athletic with greater muscle thickness.
A classification characterized by muscularity and relatively lower fat compared with endomorphic types.
A somatotype often linked to power/strength-friendly builds, featuring higher muscle mass.
A classification typically referring to individuals over 65 years of age.
A general age grouping often used for adults past typical retirement age (commonly 65+).
A life stage associated with aging-related changes in muscle, bone, and recovery capacity.
A broad classification describing later-life adults, often defined by context-specific cutoffs.
An age category frequently used in research/clinical settings for senior populations.
A group term for later adulthood where sarcopenia and bone loss risks increase.
A classification describing individuals in later life stages, often 65 and older.
An age grouping used in training contexts to reflect age-associated physiological changes.
Lower-than-normal bone mineral density that is not low enough to be classified as osteoporosis.
A bone density state between normal and osteoporosis, indicating increased fracture risk vs normal.
Reduced BMD that is mild-to-moderate, often considered a precursor to osteoporosis.
A diagnosis of low bone mass that signals compromised skeletal strength but not severe osteoporosis.
A condition of decreased bone density that raises risk but is less severe than osteoporosis.
Subnormal bone mineral density that indicates bone loss without meeting osteoporosis threshold.
Lower bone density that warrants attention to loading, nutrition, and hormonal health.
A stage of decreased BMD that can progress to osteoporosis if risk factors persist.
A disease characterized by very low bone mineral density and increased fracture risk.
A skeletal disorder in which bone strength is reduced, increasing likelihood of fractures.
A condition of significant bone loss and structural deterioration of bone tissue.
Severely reduced BMD associated with fragility fractures and compromised bone integrity.
A disease state where bones become porous/brittle, elevating fracture risk.
A bone disease marked by low mass and weakened microarchitecture.
A condition in which bone is so weakened that fracture risk rises substantially.
A severe bone density loss disorder characterized by fragile bones and fracture susceptibility.
The period of fastest growth in stature during adolescence.
The point in adolescence where height increases at the greatest rate.
A maturational marker representing maximum growth rate in body height.
The peak of the adolescent growth spurt, often used to time youth training considerations.
The time window where yearly (or monthly) height gain is highest.
The maximal rate of increase in stature occurring during puberty-related growth acceleration.
A key adolescent milestone indicating the apex of linear growth speed.
The period when the adolescent experiences their fastest upward growth in height.
Muscle activation that occurs prior to ground contact to increase joint stability.
Anticipatory muscle activity before landing/contact to stiffen joints and improve control.
Neuromuscular activation before impact that helps prepare tissues for force absorption.
A preparatory contraction pattern that can reduce injury risk during landings and cutting.
Muscle ‘turn-on’ before contact that enhances stability and force handling capacity.
Feedforward activation that increases joint stiffness before external load/impact occurs.
Pre-contact activation that helps stabilize joints and manage landing forces.
Anticipatory activation before landing that improves alignment, stiffness, and protection.
The developmental period marked by sexual maturation and rapid growth.
A maturation stage characterized by endocrine changes that drive reproductive and physical development.
The biological process leading to sexual maturity, often accompanied by growth spurts.
A developmental window featuring hormonal changes that affect body composition and performance.
The period where reproductive capability develops and secondary sex characteristics emerge.
A maturation phase involving increased sex hormones and accelerated growth in stature and mass.
The stage of maturation that initiates rapid physical development and sexual maturation.
A developmental period where hormonal changes drive adult reproductive maturation and growth.
Exercise that causes muscles to contract against an external resistance.
Training that applies load (external or bodyweight) to stimulate strength and tissue adaptation.
A form of exercise using resistance to challenge muscles and produce mechanical tension.
Exercise involving external load or opposing force to improve strength, hypertrophy, or endurance.
Loading-based exercise that creates muscular force against resistance (weights, bands, machines, body mass).
Exercise that overloads muscle via resistance to promote neuromuscular and structural adaptations.
A training mode where muscles work against resistance to improve force production capacity.
Work performed against external force to strengthen muscle and connective tissues.
Age-related loss of skeletal muscle mass and strength.
A progressive decline in muscle size and function associated with aging.
The aging-linked reduction in muscle tissue and force-producing capacity.
Loss of muscle mass/strength with age that contributes to frailty and reduced performance.
An age-associated syndrome involving decreased lean mass, strength, and physical function.
A decline in skeletal muscle quantity and quality seen in older populations.
Age-related muscle wasting that impacts strength, power, and mobility.
The progressive loss of muscle mass and function that occurs with advancing age.
An older adult, often classified as age 65 or older.
A life-stage classification typically used for individuals in older adulthood.
A common demographic label for later-life adults (often 65+ depending on context).
An age group where aging-related changes in recovery, bone, and muscle are more prominent.
A classification used in health/fitness contexts to describe older adult populations.
A term often synonymous with older adult in training and clinical settings.
A later-life demographic category frequently defined around retirement age.
An age classification for older individuals, commonly beginning around 65 years.
The length of time an individual has participated in structured training.
A measure of training experience reflecting years/months of consistent program exposure.
How long a person has been training in a systematic way (not just chronological age).
A useful indicator of readiness for advanced programming and loading complexity.
A practical metric describing exposure history to resistance training or sport training.
Training experience duration that helps predict adaptation rate and technical proficiency.
An experience-based age describing how long structured training has been performed.
The amount of time spent in organized, progressive training that shapes adaptation potential.
A general term referring to children and adolescents.
A broad classification for individuals not yet in adulthood (childhood through adolescence).
A demographic group typically spanning prepubertal and pubertal developmental stages.
A life-stage grouping where growth and maturation processes are still occurring.
A general label for young individuals whose biological maturity may vary widely.
A category encompassing children and teens with ongoing growth and development.
A broad term covering developmental stages prior to full adult maturity.
A group term for non-adult populations including kids and adolescents.
A child or adolescent participating in organized sport or training.
A developing athlete whose growth and maturation status influences training response and risk.
A youth participant in sport where training should account for biological age and PHV timing.
A pre-adult athlete with ongoing growth, making movement skill and safe loading priorities.
An athlete in childhood/adolescence whose readiness varies by maturation, not just age.
A sport participant who is still developing physically and neurologically.
A youth sport trainee whose program should reflect growth plate considerations and maturation.
A child or teen athlete whose training must balance skill, strength, and long-term development.
